title: Maksym Nikitin
text:
Maksym (Maxim) Kostiantynovych Nikitin (; born 5 October 1994) is a Ukrainian <a href="ice%20dancer">ice dancer</a>. With his skating partner, <a href="Oleksandra%20Nazarova">Oleksandra Nazarova</a>, he is the <a href="2015%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2015 World Junior</a> bronze medalist and <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202012%20Winter%20Youth%20Olympics">2012 Youth Olympic</a> silver medalist. On the senior level, they are the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202017%20Winter%20Universiade">2017 Winter Universiade</a> champions, <a href="2014%20CS%20Warsaw%20Cup">2014 CS Warsaw Cup</a> silver medalists, 2016 <a href="Cup%20of%20Nice">Cup of Nice</a> bronze medalists, six-time <a href="Ukrainian%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">Ukrainian national</a> champions (2015, 2017, 2018, 2020–2022) and qualified a spot for Ukraine at the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202018%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Qualification">2018 Winter Olympics</a>.
Personal life.
Maxim Nikitin was born on 5 October 1994 in <a href="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, Ukraine. Around 2012, he enrolled at the Kharkiv State Academy of Physical Culture, where he is a correspondence student.
Career.
Early career.
Nikitin was a recreational single skater in his early years. Around 2004, Halyna Churilova encouraged him and <a href="Oleksandra%20Nazarova">Oleksandra Nazarova</a>, also a single skater from Kharkiv, to form an ice dancing partnership.
Nazarova/Nikitin debuted on the <a href="ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">ISU Junior Grand Prix</a> series in <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">2010</a>. They placed 11th in <a href="Graz">Graz</a>, Austria and 7th in <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>, England. Churilova coached the team in their hometown.
In the 2011–2012 season, they made no appearances on the JGP series but were sent to the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202012%20Winter%20Youth%20Olympics">Youth Olympics</a> in January 2012 in <a href="Innsbruck">Innsbruck</a>, Austria. They won the silver medal behind Russia's <a href="Anna%20Yanovskaya">Anna Yanovskaya</a> / <a href="Sergey%20Mozgov">Sergey Mozgov</a>.
2012–2013 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin placed 5th at both of their <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">2012 JGP</a> events and were assigned to their first <a href="2013%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">World Junior Championships</a>. At the latter competition, held in late February and early March 2013 in <a href="Milan">Milan</a>, Italy, the duo placed 12th in the short dance, 9th in the free dance, and 11th overall. After the event, Churilova advised them to join Russian coach <a href="Alexander%20Zhulin">Alexander Zhulin</a>. They relocated to <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a> to train with Zhulin and Oleg Volkov.
2013–2014 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin won silver at both of their <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">2013 JGP</a> assignments and qualified for the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Figure%20Skating%20Final">JGP Final</a>. They placed fifth at the Final, held in December 2013 in <a href="Fukuoka">Fukuoka</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. In March 2014, they finished fifth at the <a href="2014%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">World Junior Championships</a> in <a href="Sofia">Sofia</a>, Bulgaria, having ranked seventh in the short dance and fourth in the free dance.
2014–2015 season: Senior debut.
Nazarova/Nikitin continued training in Moscow in the 2014–2015 season. At the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">Junior Grand Prix</a> event in <a href="Courchevel">Courchevel</a>, France, they ranked fifth in the short dance and third in the free dance. The duo finished fourth overall, 0.54 shy of third place. They won the bronze medal at their next JGP event, in <a href="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>, Estonia, after placing sixth in the short and third in the free dance.
Making their senior international debut, Nazarova/Nikitin won the silver medal at the <a href="2014%20CS%20Warsaw%20Cup">Warsaw Cup</a>, a <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20ISU%20Challenger%20Series">Challenger Series</a> event in November 2014. After winning the Ukrainian senior national title, they were named in Ukraine's team to the <a href="2015%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">European Championships</a>, held in late January 2015 in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>, Sweden. Ranked 12th in the short dance and 11th in the free dance, the two finished 11th overall.
In early March, the two competed at the <a href="2015%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2015 World Junior Championships</a> in <a href="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>, Estonia. They were awarded the bronze medal after placing fifth in the short dance, second in the free dance, and third overall behind <a href="Anna%20Yanovskaya">Anna Yanovskaya</a> / <a href="Sergey%20Mozgov">Sergey Mozgov</a> of Russia and <a href="Lorraine%20McNamara">Lorraine McNamara</a> / <a href="Quinn%20Carpenter">Quinn Carpenter</a> of the United States. It was Ukraine's first podium finish at the event since <a href="2000%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2000</a>. At the end of the same month, Nazarova/Nikitin competed on the senior level at the <a href="2015%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2015 World Championships</a> in <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, China; they ranked 17th in both segments and overall.
2015–2016 season.
Making their <a href="ISU%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Figure%20Skating">Grand Prix</a> debut, Nazarova/Nikitin finished 7th at the <a href="2015%20Skate%20America">2015 Skate America</a>. They withdrew from the Ukrainian Championships due to Nazarova's knee injury. The duo returned to competition in late March 2016 at the <a href="2016%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">World Championships</a> in <a href="Boston">Boston</a>. Ranked 20th in the short dance, they narrowly qualified for the free dance where they placed 18th, resulting in a final placement of 19th.
Deciding to change coaches, Nazarova/Nikitin joined <a href="Igor%20Shpilband">Igor Shpilband</a> and <a href="Fabian%20Bourzat">Fabian Bourzat</a> in <a href="Novi%2C%20Michigan">Novi, Michigan</a> in late June 2016.
2016–2017 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin opened their season with a bronze medal at the <a href="International%20Cup%20of%20Nice">International Cup of Nice</a>. They finished 7th at their Grand Prix assignment, the <a href="2016%20Troph%C3%A9e%20de%20France">2016 Trophée de France</a>, and 9th at the <a href="2017%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2017 European Championships</a> in <a href="Ostrava">Ostrava</a>, Czech Republic.
In February, they received the gold medal at the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202017%20Winter%20Universiade">2017 Winter Universiade</a> in <a href="Almaty">Almaty</a>, Kazakhstan. In March, they placed 15th at the <a href="2017%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2017 World Championships</a> in <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>, Finland. Due to their result, Ukraine <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%202018%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Qualification">qualified</a> a spot in the ice dancing event at the <a href="2018%20Winter%20Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Pyeongchang">Pyeongchang</a>, South Korea.
2017–2018 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin won the bronze medal at the <a href="2017%20CS%20Lombardia%20Trophy">2017 CS Lombardia Trophy</a> and the <a href="2017%20CS%20Warsaw%20Cup">2017 CS Warsaw Cup</a>, and placed fourth at the <a href="2017%20CS%20Ice%20Star">2017 CS Ice Star</a>. At their lone Grand Prix assignment for the year, <a href="2017%20NHK%20Trophy">2017 NHK Trophy</a>, they placed sixth. They placed eleventh at the <a href="2018%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">European Championships</a>, before competing at their first <a href="2018%20Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Pyeongchang">Pyeongchang</a>, <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>, where they placed a surprising twenty-first. They concluded with the <a href="2018%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2018 World Championships</a>, placing fifteenth.
After this season ended they left Igor Shpilband in Novi, Michigan, and began training only under Fabian Bourzat in France. 
2018–2019 season.
The new season began at the <a href="2018%20CS%20Nebelhorn%20Trophy">2018 CS Nebelhorn Trophy</a>, where they struggled, placing ninth. Assigned to two Grand Prix events, they placed eighth at <a href="2018%20Skate%20America">Skate America</a> and ninth at <a href="2018%20NHK%20Trophy">NHK Trophy</a>. They did not finish at the Ukrainian Championships. Due to injury, They withdrew from European Championships, with <a href="Darya%20Popova">Darya Popova</a> / <a href="Volodymyr%20Byelikov">Volodymyr Byelikov</a> winning the former and attending the latter as the Ukrainian competitor. At the <a href="2019%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2019 World Championships</a>, Nazarova/Nikitin placed twentieth.
2019–2020 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin began the season at the <a href="2019%20CS%20Lombardia%20Trophy">2019 CS Lombardia Trophy</a>, where they placed fourth in both programs to win the bronze medal overall. They went on to win the bronze medal at the <a href="2019%20CS%20Ice%20Star">2019 CS Ice Star</a> where they set a personal best in the <a href="Rhythm%20Dance">Rhythm Dance</a> and overall score. 
Between <a href="2019%20CS%20Ice%20Star">2019 CS Ice Star</a> and the <a href="2019%20Bosphorus%20Cup">2019 Bosphorus Cup</a> Nazarova/Nikitin announced that they had ended their partnership with Fabian Bourzat. They returned to Kharkiv to train mainly under Halyna Churilova, and to occasionally train under <a href="Alexander%20Zhulin">Alexander Zhulin</a>. 
They went on to win two other international events and a silver medal at the <a href="2019%20Bosphorus%20Cup">2019 Bosphorus Cup</a>. Later that year, they won the <a href="Ukrainian%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">Ukraine Championships</a>. 
National champions again, Nazarova/Nikitin finished the season at the <a href="2020%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2020 European Championships</a>, where they placed tenth. They had been assigned to compete at the <a href="2020%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">World Championships</a> in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, but these were cancelled as a result of the <a href="2019-20%20COVID-19%20pandemic">coronavirus pandemic</a>.
2020–2021 season.
Nazarova/Nikitin debuted at the <a href="2020%20CS%20Budapest%20Trophy">2020 CS Budapest Trophy</a>, winning the gold medal. They competed on the <a href="2020-21%20ISU%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Figure%20Skating">Grand Prix</a> at the <a href="2020%20Rostelecom%20Cup">2020 Rostelecom Cup</a>, placing sixth. They placed twentieth at the <a href="2021%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2021 World Championships</a> in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>. Their World result qualified a berth for a Ukrainian dance team at the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>.
2021–2022 season.
Beginning the season on the <a href="2021-22%20ISU%20Challenger%20Series">Challenger series</a>, Nazarova/Nikitin won the silver medal at the <a href="2021%20CS%20Denis%20Ten%20Memorial%20Challenge">2021 CS Denis Ten Memorial Challenge</a>. On the <a href="2021-22%20ISU%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Figure%20Skating">Grand Prix</a>, they were eighth at the <a href="2021%20NHK%20Trophy">2021 NHK Trophy</a>.
After winning the Viktor Petrenko Cup, Nazarova/Nikitin won their sixth Ukrainian national title, and were named to their second <a href="Ukraine%20at%20the%202022%20Winter%20Olympics">Ukrainian Olympic team</a>. Competing first at the <a href="2022%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2022 European Championships</a>, they finished tenth.
Competitive highlights.
"GP: <a href="ISU%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Figure%20Skating">Grand Prix</a>; CS: <a href="ISU%20Challenger%20Series">Challenger Series</a>; JGP: <a href="ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">Junior Grand Prix</a>"
